Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2011 12:27AM melissah wrote: I had skin sparing bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction and haven't found it to be terribly painful.  Sometimes it hurts but usually a couple of extra strength tylenol take care of it.  The first couple of weeks after the surgery I really took it easy.  Slept a lot and stayed quiet.  I also took pain medication when needed.  At two weeks I tried the tylenol and it worked fine  It's more uncomfortable than painful.  Once the healing starts there is a tendency to have tingling and itching beneath the skin that you can't really scratch because the skin is numb on the outside.  I find benedryl works for that. The tissue expanders seem to shift around a little bit and sometimes they are uncomfortable but changing position or mild stretching helps with that.  I had 400cc's of saline put in each TE at the time of mastectomy.  I haven't had a "fill" yet which I've heard can be uncomfortable for a few days.  Other people have had extreme pain from the muscle spasms.  I guess it depends on the individual, the plastic surgeon, etc.  Overall it hasn't been too bad.  Just my experience - I know everyone is different. Best wishes and feel free to PM me if you have other questions.  Melissa

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 03:33PM melissah wrote: I had my surgery at Banner Good Samaritan and the BS was Dr. V. Evani.  He's amazing and so nice.  He spent almost 2 hours with my husband and I prior to surgery going over all the details. I used a plastic surgeon who is new in Phoenix.  He's extremely good - his name is Lewis Andres, M.D.  I'm 3 1/2 weeks post surgery and haven't had any problems.  I've been very pleased with the care I had at the hospital, and all the follow-up.  If you google Dr. Andres, look at his credentials.  They're impressive and since he's new in Phoenix, he's still building his practice so is interested in taking on new patients.  He did some special training at Mayo in Rochester after his residency specifically for breast reconstruction.  I think he's the only surgeon in Phoenix that does some of the new "flap" surgery.   Don't know if your mom is having reconstruction but if so, I would definitely recommend him. Also, Dr. Evani's office staff is wonderful and they coordinated everything.  Your mom's primary care will still likely have to take care of getting the prior authorizations though.   Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2011 09:05PM melissah wrote: I was diagnosed on 8/25 and had my BMX with TE's on 10/12.  I was talking to the genetic counselor and she said something that really stuck in my mind.  She said that breast cancer is a patient emergency but rarely a medical emergency.  For some reason that really reassured me and made the wait easier.  In a way, I'm sort of glad I had the time.  It took awhile to get used to the idea that I have cancer, I had a lot of stuff at work to wrap up before taking time off and it also gave me a chance to get a second surgical opinion,  I don't know if this has been at all reassuring for you but I hope so.  I was pretty frantic when I was first diagnosed but I definitely calmed down the more I read and figured out what I wanted to do.  The first surgeon I saw suggested a lumpectomy with radiation but for several reasons (family history, dense tissue, numerous previous biopsies) I felt very strongly that I wanted a BMX.  The second surgeon was in total agreement and the validation made me feel better about my decision.  I'm sorry you're joining this group, but I've found so much good information here that has helped ease my mind on many levels and I hope you do too.  My very best wishes to you and hang in there.  You're in the toughest point of the whole thing right now.  No doubt about it - the waiting is horrible.  Stay strong! Melissa

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2011 02:29PM melissah wrote: I had BMX and TEs last Wed.  My pain level hasn't been too bad.  The thing that's driving me crazy is the itching.  I told the BS and PS that I'm allergic to most adhesives and evidently they didn't hear me (or didn't listen???).  Anyway, we took the dressings off for the first time yesterday and I have blisters and redness where the tape was.  My husband put new dressings on and took most of the tape off (the dressings are anchored by the bra they gave me) but I'm still itching.  I guess it could also be part of the healing process.  Overall, I have to say this wasn't as bad as I thought it was going to be. I offer my best wishes and prayers to those with surgery coming up.  You can do this!
